Award.AwardTitle: Cardinal Science Scholars: Enhancing Student Opportunities and Retention

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The project at Otterbein College is providing scholarships and enhanced academic and co-curricular experiences to students majoring in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Chemistry, Computer Science, Mathematics, or Physics. Fourteen scholars, who entered as first-year students, are receiving four years of support and fourteen scholars are receiving two years of support following their transfer to Otterbein after completing a 2-year program at a regional community college. Scholars, selected based on both previous academic experience, and an on-campus interview, are participating in an active learning community whose components include a three day-long summer immersion experience, programming with the Center for Career Planning, residence in a living-learning house, a focused seminar program, and a mentoring triad which includes a peer, a faculty member, and a STEM professional. All S-STEM scholars are eligible for a paid summer research experience as an explicit part of the program designed to help students maintain an interest in STEM fields, improve the likelihood they will earn higher GPAs and persist in the major. The project, through its recruiting strategies with local high schools, is leading to greater retention in STEM majors and access to STEM careers for students from groups traditionally underrepresented in chemistry, particularly first-generation college students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Using funds from the National Science Foundation S-STEM program, Otterbein University created our Cardinal Science Scholars program. During the lifetime of this award, we welcomed 31 Scholars majoring in Biochemistry & Molecular Biology (BMB), Chemistry, Computer Science, Mathematics, Physics, or Engineering. Our Scholars had diverse backgrounds - 52% were female, 19% minority students, 29% first generation college students and 23% transfer students. Our Broader Impacts included strengthening our relationship with regional community colleges, visiting their STEM clubs and developing or renewing dual enrollment programs and 2 + 2 transfer pathways.

The Intellectual Merit of our program involved connecting Scholars to an enriched educational experience and unique co-curricular programming that supported our Scholars academically and facilitated a post-graduate career path. To build a sense of community and introduce the Scholars to each other, upper level students and STEM faculty, Scholars participated in a three-day summer orientation and, in the case of some transfer students, participated in summer research prior to starting their Otterbein careers. During their first year on campus, Scholars participated in peer mentoring, intrusive advising, discussions about study strategies, and bi-weekly meetings with other Scholars and faculty mentors. As Scholars progressed through their undergraduate career, they met with alumni to discuss different career paths either individually, or through alumni panels focused on industrial careers or graduate school. Together with our Center for Career and Professional Development, we offered career-related programming, such as best practices for writing resumes and personal statements, putting together a thoughtful LinkedIn profile, improving interviewing skills, and internship and job searching strategies. Throughout their undergraduate careers, Scholars reflected on their progress, how the program impacted them, and their changing or more directed career path.

Because of early exposure to career programming, some of our Scholars began research experiences as early as their first year and 86% of students participated in research or internship experiences prior to graduating from Otterbein, a rate that is double that of their peers. Of our 31 Scholars, 27 (87%) graduated in a STEM field within four years, which is more than double the four-year graduation rate of their STEM peers (41%). All of the Scholars are employed (64%) or continuing their education in a STEM-related field (36%).

As part of the dissemination of our project, we organized a symposium for regional S-STEM programs at the 2015 inaugural Ohio Project Kaleidoscope (OH-PKAL) conference held at Otterbein University. This not only allowed institutions to share information about their programs, but we could also learn best practices from one another and network with other program directors creating a broader impact.

We are eager to carry the momentum generated from this NSF award forward and continue some of the programming elements more broadly to create a more supportive and career-focused community for all students within our STEM departments.
